Any nonzero natural number is the product of an odd part `m` and a power of
two `2 ^ k`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∃ k m, Odd m ∧ n = 2 ^ k * m
name: Nat.exists_eq_two_pow_mul_odd
docString:
Any nonzero natural number is the product of an odd part `m` and a power of
two `2 ^ k`.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even n → Even a → Even (n % a)
name: Even.mod_even
docString: If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `0` and `n` is equal to `0`.

name: Nat.zero_mul
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `0` and `n` is equal to `0`.

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if `n` is not odd. Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ ¬Odd n
name: Nat.even_iff_not_odd
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if `n` is not odd. Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.

If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

If `n` is a nonzero natural number and `p ≠ 1`, then there are natural numbers `e`
and `n'` such that `n'` is not divisible by `p` and `n = p^e * n'`.

name: Nat.exists_eq_pow_mul_and_not_dvd
docString:
If `n` is a nonzero natural number and `p ≠ 1`, then there are natural numbers `e`
and `n'` such that `n'` is not divisible by `p` and `n = p^e * n'`.

If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Odd n → Even a → Odd (n % a)
name: Odd.mod_even
docString: If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

`n : ℕ` is a _weird_ number if and only if it is abundant but not pseudoperfect.

type: ℕ → Prop
name: Nat.Weird
docString: `n : ℕ` is a _weird_ number if and only if it is abundant but not pseudoperfect.

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

Multiplication by `(n + 1 : ℕ)` behaves as expected.

type: ∀ {M : Type u} [self : AddMonoid M] (n : ℕ) (x : M), AddMonoid.nsmul (n + 1) x = AddMonoid.nsmul n x + x
name: AddMonoid.nsmul_succ
docString: Multiplication by `(n + 1 : ℕ)` behaves as expected.

Exactly `n / p` naturals in `(0, n]` are multiples of `p`.

type: ∀ (n p : ℕ), (Finset.filter (fun x => p ∣ x) (Finset.Ioc 0 n)).card = n / p
name: Nat.Ioc_filter_dvd_card_eq_div
docString: Exactly `n / p` naturals in `(0, n]` are multiples of `p`.

The primorial `n#` of `n` is the product of the primes less than or equal to `n`.

type: ℕ → ℕ
name: primorial
docString: The primorial `n#` of `n` is the product of the primes less than or equal to `n`.

The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

name: Nat.one_lt_mul_iff
docString:
The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

Exactly `n / p` naturals in `[1, n]` are multiples of `p`.
See `Nat.card_multiples'` for an alternative spelling of the statement.

type: ∀ (n p : ℕ), (Finset.filter (fun e => p ∣ e + 1) (Finset.range n)).card = n / p
name: Nat.card_multiples
docString:
Exactly `n / p` naturals in `[1, n]` are multiples of `p`.
See `Nat.card_multiples'` for an alternative spelling of the statement.

The product of two `n`-smooth numbers is an `n`-smooth number.

type: ∀ {m₁ m₂ n : ℕ}, m₁ ∈ n.smoothNumbers → m₂ ∈ n.smoothNumbers → m₁ * m₂ ∈ n.smoothNumbers
name: Nat.mul_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: The product of two `n`-smooth numbers is an `n`-smooth number.

There are exactly `⌊N/n⌋` positive multiples of `n` that are `≤ N`.
See `Nat.card_multiples` for a "shifted-by-one" version.

type: ∀ (N n : ℕ), (Finset.filter (fun k => k ≠ 0 ∧ n ∣ k) (Finset.range N.succ)).card = N / n
name: Nat.card_multiples'
docString:
There are exactly `⌊N/n⌋` positive multiples of `n` that are `≤ N`.
See `Nat.card_multiples` for a "shifted-by-one" version.

The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

type: ℕ → Type
name: ZMod
docString: The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

A single variable `n` is represented by a sum with coefficient `1` and monomial `n`.

type: ℕ → Linarith.Sum
name: Linarith.var
docString: A single variable `n` is represented by a sum with coefficient `1` and monomial `n`.

`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

type: {R : Type u_1} → [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] → R → Prop
name: IsPrimePow
docString:
`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

On a finite product space in `n` variables, for a natural number `n`, a product of integrable
functions depending on each coordinate is integrable.

type:
∀ {�� : Type u_1} [inst : RCLike ��] {n : ℕ} {E : Fin n → Type u_2}
  [inst_1 : (i : Fin n) → MeasureTheory.MeasureSpace (E i)]
  [inst_2 : ∀ (i : Fin n), MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite MeasureTheory.volume] {f : (i : Fin n) → E i → ��},
  (∀ (i : Fin n), MeasureTheory.Integrable (f i) MeasureTheory.volume) →
    MeasureTheory.Integrable (fun x => ∏ i : Fin n, f i (x i)) MeasureTheory.volume
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.fin_nat_prod
docString:
On a finite product space in `n` variables, for a natural number `n`, a product of integrable
functions depending on each coordinate is integrable.
